awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Resolving and mapping of nanoscale heterogeneities in polymer gels and determination of their impact on properties.
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary:

Polymer hydrogels are jelly-like materials that consist primarily of water, and are held together by a sparse mesh of long molecules within the liquid. Hydrogels are ubiquitous, finding use in medical materials such as contact lenses, energy materials such as battery membranes, separation matrices for the chemical industry, commodities such as diapers, etc. These materials have been known for many decades to be non-uniform on a very small (nanometer) scale. This project seeks to reveal the nature of these non-uniformities and explore their relation to variations in performance. It will do so by utilizing a number of new types of super-resolution microscopy techniques together with complementary materials structure-property characterization approaches.  The educational component leverages the research program as a platform to inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers. The scope includes: (a) outreach to underrepresented groups in STEM through creation of hands-on learning activities, videos and mentorship of K-12 students via an online learning portal; (b) expansion of polymer content and development of innovative curricula using evidence-based approaches such as primary literature in the classroom and student teaching in the context of service learning; and (c) mentoring through undergraduate and graduate polymer science research.



Technical Summary:

This work will integrate research, teaching, outreach and mentoring around elucidating the impact of uncontrolled nanoscale heterogeneities on the structure-property relationships of polymer gels. The objective is to map nanoscale variations in crosslink density of gels in real space and quantify the consequent non-affine deformation. These fundamental morphological studies will establish the contributions of network spatial heterogeneities to deviations from the predictions of classic theories of elasticity and reptation. The timeliness of the proposal draws on the recent ability of optical superresolution microscopies to non-destructively image the nanostructure of solvent-swollen polymer systems. The proposed work will answer an important scientific question -- what is the nanoscale structure of a gel -- and thus offer potential impact to a number of industries.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Polymer gels are industrially important jelly-like materials that consist primarily of solvent, and are held together by a sparse mesh of long molecules within the liquid. These materials have been known for many decades to be non-uniform on a very small (nano- and micrometer) scale. This project integrated research, teaching, outreach and mentoring around the study of establishing the nature of and elucidating the impact of these uncontrolled nano- and microscale variations in structure, known as spatial heterogeneities, on the mechanical properties of gels.

The primary intellectual merit outcome of this project is that through the case study of a specific gel system where the polymer is poly(N-isopropylacrylamide), and the use of optical microscopy techniques known as super-resolution microscopy, it advanced understanding of the nature of the structure of gels on the scale of tens of nanometers to hundreds of nanometers, and how this structure impacts a macro scale mechanical property known as shear modulus.
Specific advances include revealing the nature of polymer density variations in certain small particles made of gels and how they can vary at the single particle level; establishing a new means to quantify the rates at which the building block molecules react while forming small particles made of gels; revealing the structure of certain gels on the scale of hundreds of nanometers and providing new insight into the origins of this microscale structure; discovering an anomalous trend in the mechanical properties of certain surface attached heterogeneous gels and providing new insight into the impact of nano- and micro-scale structural features on the mechanical properties of gels; inventing a relatively simple means to modulate size and chemical group distribution in small gel particles; and measuring with high resolution the fluctuations of molecluar level building blocks of the long polymer chains in gels.

These important results have been disseminated to communities of interest through four peer reviewed publications with a fifth currently under peer review; invited and contributed talks and posters at conferences and universities; and a PhD thesis.
The broader impacts of this project are related to outreach, teaching and mentoring. The outreach efforts provided young students and their families exposure to STEM and the possibilities of careers in STEM. This included, in person K-12 and Family science workshops at 9 local area schools and after school science programs that utilized activities developed for and hosted on the online portal, Curiosity Machine; multi session virtual workshops consisting of hands on learning activities for K-12 students including a nine multi-part set of hands on learning activities, demos and lectures developed for and run as part of the RPI School of Engineering’s 12-day long Introduction to Engineering PREFACE program; and introduction to materials engineering workshops during outreach weekends for high school students organized by local chapters of engineering student professional organizations. The research aspects of the project provided various training and professional development opportunities for a Post-Doc, graduate students, and undergraduate students. These opportunities resulted in the participants gaining exposure to diverse fields like polymer characterization, optics, material characterization and experience building their professional network, and academic, communication, leadership and other transferable skills. Other undergraduate students who participated in building an educational augmented reality molecule building app got experience building an educational app by applying fundamental concepts in physics, applying design to produce an educational app that meets specified needs with consideration of educational factors, functioning effectively on a team whose members together provide leadership, create a collaborative and inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks and meet objectives associated with building an educational app, and acquiring and applying new knowledge as needed using appropriate learning strategies. Finally, the project impacted teaching and educational experiences in two broad categories. First, by leveraging novel visualizations in immersive and interactive media through the PI's participation in RPI's Molecularium project and the associated ongoing development of an Augmented Reality Molecule Building Game and ongoing upgrade of the codebase of Nanospace, a K-12 educational webgame site that previously had a large user base (~100,000 annual users) and has been offline since 2021. Second, by applying thematic learning to undergraduate curricula, examples of which include increasing polymer content in four undergraduate courses through a combination of invited lectures and development of lecture content. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/26/2024
Modified by: Chaitanya Ullal
